ALLEGATION:
It is alleged that the agency did not provide a response on a case emergency
from 12/27/21 – 12/29/21. The agency on call worker was unable to be reached
during this time. When worker and supervisor were contacted, they indicated
2

there was no one working until after 01/01/2022. It appears that there I not an
emergency plan for cases or staff were not adequately aware of the process.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A, age 5, is currently placed in the home of her maternal aunt where she has
been residing since 11/05/2021. Youth A ingested a half bottle of liquid Tylenol on
12/27/2021 and was taken to the hospital.
The reporting source had no additional information to add to this allegation. She
did report there were a case conference meeting held on 01/05/2022 and a Team
Decision Making meeting (TMD) held on 01/12/2022 with Youth A and her
caregiver with the agency and governmental worker.
I interviewed the agency caseworker (Staff 1) regarding the allegation. She
reported she received a telephone call from another governmental worker on
12/29/2021 regarding Youth A who is on her case load. Staff 1 reports that during
the call the governmental worker expressed concern about the office protocol
during the holiday but failed to mention Youth A’s name or the nature of the incident
she was concerned about. Staff 1 said she explained to the worker that the office is
closed due to the holidays, however telephone calls to the agency are transferred
to the supervisor on call. She said the governmental worker never mentioned to her
that there was a complaint on a child or a home. Staff 1 said the governmental
worker was only concerned about the office being closed until 01/03/2022 and
requested the name of the agency supervisor. She said she provided the name
and telephone number of the agency supervisor and they hung up. Staff 1 said she
was contacted by her supervisor on 12/29/2021 who provided her with Youth A's
name and the nature of a complaint. She said she went to the home when she
received the information on 12/29/2021 and spoke with the caregiver and Youth A.
She said a safety plan was put in place for the caregiver and Youth A. She said
since she was assigned to Youth A’s case, she discussed with the caregiver the
importance of contacting the agency or Staff 1 in the case of an emergency
because the caregiver had Staff 1 telephone number.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 regarding the allegation. She reported on 12/29/2021
around 1:30pm she received a text message from Staff 1 informing her that a
governmental worker wanted to talk with her regarding Youth A. Supervisor 1 said
she contacted the telephone number provided to her from Staff 1. She said she was
informed by the governmental worker there was a complaint made on the home
regarding Youth A on 12/27/21 and that the governmental worker had tried to
inform the agency to no avail. She said the governmental worker explained to her
that she sent an email but did not receive a bounce back saying the office was
closed or that Supervisor 1 was out of the office. Supervisor 1 said she apologized
to the worker as she was the supervisor on call and had not received a message.
Supervisor 1 explained that the telephone system in the building had not been
working properly for months but the agency assumed it was fixed before the start of
3

the holiday season. Supervisor 1 said she apologized repeatedly assuring that an
away email had been set up on the agency telephone prior to closing the office.
Supervisor 1 said she explained the after-hour phone protocol to the government
worker. Supervisor 1 explained that the agency receptionist is required to check
the phone for any messages. The receptionist then forwards the messages to the
supervisor’s extension. Supervisor 1 stated she explained that if someone calls, the
call goes directly to the supervisor extension which in turns goes directly to the
supervisor cell phones. However, due to technical problems with the telephone
system, this process did not work properly.
Supervisor 1 said she informed the governmental worker that the situation would be
taken care of immediately with Youth A. She said she informed Staff 1 the nature
of the complaint and requested her to go to the home on 12/29/2021, to complete a
wellness check and develop a safety plan for Youth A.
Supervisor 1 said the caregiver of Youth A had her assigned agency caseworker
telephone number and she was aware that she could call the caseworker (Staff 1)
at any time regarding Youth A. She said the caregiver was trained on the agency
policies and procedures and signed documentation stating she understood the
process. She said the caregiver called another government worker to report that
Youth A had ingested a half of bottle of liquid Tylenol and was taken to the hospital.
She said when Staff 1 spoke with the caregiver, the caregiver reported she acted
abruptly and called another governmental worker because that was the first number
she found at the time. The caregiver did not contact Homes for Black Children
regarding Youth A and the Tylenol incident.
I interviewed the Chief Administrator regarding the allegation. She reported the
agency was having issues with the telephone system prior to this incident. She said
since the incident, she has contacted the technology company to work on the
system because when messages were left, the messages were being erased and
not saved therefore, the receptionist were not getting the messages to leave for the
on-call supervisor. She said the company technician came out, worked on the
system and provided training to the receptionist and now phone calls can be
answered remotely.
I reviewed another governmental worker report regarding the allegation. The
following information were noted from the report:
 The caregiver called the governmental worker and reported that Youth A had
ingested a half bottle of Tylenol. It was reported the incident occurred on
12/27/2021, around 11:00pm but then the story changed and said the
incident occurred around 6pm. The caregiver delayed taking Youth A to the
hospital and did not have an explanation of how Youth A swallowed the
medication.
 It was discovered that the Tylenol was in liquid form.
4

 The caregiver reported that Youth A was staying overnight with her maternal
grandmother’s house (MGM). The MGM called the caregiver and reported
between 6-7pm she had left a bottle of children’s liquid Tylenol on a counter
and discovered Youth A had retrieved and opened the bottle. It was unsure
if Youth A ingested the medication or how much medication was in the
bottle. The MGM gave Youth A a glass of milk and watched her closely.
 Youth A fell asleep and woke up around 11:00pm complaining of abdominal
pain. The caregiver picked Youth A up and took her to the emergency room.
 Upon an assessment the medical doctor ran blood work and tests and
advised that Youth A’s Tylenol levels were below the recommendation
dosage for her age and weight.
 Youth A was discharged with instruction to follow up with her pediatrician.
 Based on another governmental worker’s report, there were insufficient
evidence of improper supervision or medical neglect of Youth A.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is suggested that Homes for Back Children revisit the procedure for reporting
unusual incidents with this foster parent. It is also suggested that the agency
telephone numbers are posted in a place where the foster parent have easy
access to obtaining the phone number when and if the need arises.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of
the following areas:
(f) Unusual incidents
5

ANALYSIS:
The agency Supervisor 1 and Chief Administrator admitted that
the agency had a faulty telephone system during the Christmas
holidays. The telephone system was not saving the messages
and erasing the messages as well causing the receptionist to
not send the messages to the supervisor.
The agency had an emergency system in place but had a faulty
telephone system, which they were aware of prior to the holiday
season prevented them from addressing an emergency in a
timely fashion. The emergency call came in 12/27/21, and they
were not able to address it until 12/29/21 due to the faulty
telephone system. The agency is found in noncompliance for
not making sure their telephone system was in proper working
condition prior to closing the office for the holidays. The
administration was aware they were having issues with the
telephone system.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Homes
for Black Children license remains unchanged.
